keyTakeAways: Sean 'Diddy' Combs is appealing his conviction and 50-month prison sentence, indicating the legal system's ongoing evaluation of the case's fairness and severity.

Combs was convicted of two counts of transportation to engage in prostitution but acquitted on more serious charges of sex trafficking and racketeering, showing a distinction in the severity of the legal outcomes.
Judge Arun Subramanian imposed a 50-month prison sentence, a $500,000 fine, and five years of probation, emphasizing the gravity of the alleged abuse of women.
Combs admitted that his actions were 'disgusting, shameful, and sick' and apologized to two women who testified against him, demonstrating personal acknowledgment of wrongdoing.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Sean 'Diddy' Combs, a prominent music mogul, is appealing his conviction and 50-month prison sentence following a federal trial in which he was found guilty of two counts of transportation to engage in prostitution, but acquitted on more serious charges of sex trafficking and racketeering. The case, centered on allegations that Combs used his influence in the music industry to coerce girlfriends into participating in 'freak-offs' with male escorts, involved testimony from women such as Cassandra Ventura and Jane, who claimed abuse and coercion. Judge Arun Subramanian imposed a substantial sentence, including a $500,000 fine and five years of probation, emphasizing accountability for the abuse of women. Combs expressed remorse during sentencing, and his legal team has now filed a notice of appeal, signaling ongoing legal and public scrutiny of the case, which has attracted international media attention due to its implications for power, celebrity behavior, and gender-based exploitation.
title: Sean 'Diddy' Combs says he plans to appeal sentence and conviction
